About Rosemary Sutcliff

Rosemary Sutcliff was a beloved author of children’s literature, whose captivating stories and complex characters have left an indelible mark on readers of all ages. Her stories were known for their engaging and entertaining narrative, as well as their meaningful and emotionally charged characters. Her protagonists were often vibrant and vivid, taking readers on a journey of self-discovery. Her unique writing style was what made her stories so enjoyable to read, and it is why her works are still cherished by many today.

For her achievements, Sutcliff was awarded a CBE (Commander of the Order of the British Empire). With her stories, she was able to capture the imaginations of adults and children alike, leaving behind a timeless legacy of joy and emotional connection.

Early and Personal Life

Rosemary Sutcliff, CBE, was born on December 14, 1920, in West Clandon, Surrey. From a young age, she was nourished by stories and a passion for reading. Growing up, her father was a naval officer and she lived in Malta and other naval bases. Sadly, she developed Still’s Disease, which kept her in a wheelchair for the rest of her life. Her mother was a dedicated storyteller and Sutcliff became deeply fascinated by Celtic and Saxon legends.

Due to her illness, Sutcliff struggled to attend school until the age of nine when she finally learned how to read. She then attended Bideford Art School for three years, graduating from the General Art Course. Later, her career as a miniaturist painter began. Sutcliff was a celebrated British novelist and children’s author, highly regarded for her depth and quality of writing. Her influence continues on to this day even though she passed away in 1992, leaving behind a powerful legacy.

Writing Career

Rosemary Sutcliff was a prolific and award-winning writer who published over 40 books for children. Her first book, The Queen Elizabeth Story, was published in 1950 and her career would span four decades. Her most notable series was Eagle of the Ninth, a five-book series, and Legends of King Arthur, a four-book series. Among her many novels were Chronicles of Robin Hood, The Armourer’s House, Brother Dustyfeet, Warrior Scarlet, and The Chief’s Daughter.

Sutcliff also wrote several picture books, such as The Roundabout Horse and A Little Dog Like You, as well as non-fiction works, such as Heroes and History and Is Anyone There? In 1960, Sutcliff won the prestigious Carnegie Medal for her book The Lantern Bearers. In 1975, she was awarded the Order of the British Empire for her services to children’s literature. Throughout her career, Sutcliff explored many different cultures and stories, creating a beloved and lasting body of work.

The Eagle of the Ninth

Rosemary Sutcliff released her classic Young Adult historical novel, ‘The Eagle of the Ninth,’ on January 1st 1954. This book was the first in her ‘Dolphin Ring Cycle’ series, which introduced readers to beloved characters and an intriguing world. The novel soon became a beloved classic, beloved by generations of readers who have kept it alive and well to this day.

In Rosemary Sutcliff’s acclaimed book, The Eagle of the Ninth, readers are taken to Roman Britain. It follows the journey of a young Roman officer who must uncover the secret behind the mysterious disappearance of the Ninth Legion. The Ninth Legion marched into the wilds of northern Britain and never returned.

Readers join a young Roman officer on a quest to uncover the truth about the lost Ninth Legion. The journey is thrilling and suspenseful, keeping readers on the edge of their seat. With beautiful descriptions of the wilds of Britain, the historical setting comes alive and immerses readers in the story. This book is a must-read for those who love a good adventure and a captivating mystery.

The Lantern Bearers

Rosemary Sutcliff’s historical novel ‘The Lantern Bearers’ was released on January 1, 1959, as part of ‘The Dolphin Ring Cycle’ series. It was a highly acclaimed book, garnering a Carnegie Medal in the year of its release. It was the fourth book in the series, expanding the characters and the world of the story.

Aquila had a difficult life. His home was destroyed in a civil war and he was taken captive by the Saxons. After years of suffering, he made a decision to start anew. He set out to reclaim his home and make something of himself, determined to put some meaning back into his life. Aquila fought hard against all odds, seeking to reclaim his homeland.

This gripping story follows Aquila on his quest. It is an inspiring tale of courage and strength in the face of great adversity. Readers will be amazed by the obstacles Aquila faces and the bravery he displays. This is a remarkable book that will leave readers inspired and touched by Aquila’s journey.

The Wanderings of Odysseus

Rosemary Sutcliff’s historical fantasy ‘The Wanderings of Odysseus’ was published on January 1, 1995. It is a work of children’s literature featuring stories from Greek mythology and is aimed at young adults. This novel is considered to be one of Sutcliff’s best works and has been widely praised for its engaging storytelling.

The Trojan War had come to an end and Troy lay in ruins. King Odysseus of Ithaca set sail with the Greek war-host, but his voyage home was far from simple. Rosemary Sutcliff re-imagined Homer’s classic epic poem The Odyssey into a captivating tale of adventure, with an array of memorable characters, powerful magicians and mythical creatures. Alan Lee brought the golden age of Greece to life with his artwork, creating a vivid image of Odysseus’ legendary journey.

Reading The Odyssey by Rosemary Sutcliff and illustrated by Alan Lee is a truly captivating experience. The classic tale of Odysseus’ voyage home was reimagined in an exciting and engaging way. Sutcliff’s writing fills the reader with a sense of wonder as they followed the Greek war-host on their journey. Lee’s artwork is also a stunning accompaniment, bringing to life the characters, magicians and mythical creatures of the golden age of Greece. For readers looking for an epic adventure, The Odyssey is definitely worth a read.
